Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Multi-Scale Modeling and Characterization of Twinning-Induced Plasticity and Fracture in Magnesium Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) collaborative research grant is to identify fundamentally validated mean-field and full-field models capable of predicting failure in Mg alloys. This is a critical step for developing materials design concepts to enable the use of lightweight Mg alloys in safety critical applications or development of deformation processing strategies. A critical, fundamental gap in the understanding of Mg alloy deformation relates to dislocation-dislocation, dislocation-twin, twin-twin, and twin-grain boundary (GB) interactions and their effects on strain hardening and damage initiation. It is now understood that (i) interactions between twin variants, such "autotwinning" and double twinning, catalyze macroscopic shear localization and (ii) crack nucleation takes place at twin-GB and twin-twin intersections. The ability to predict and mitigate these behaviors lags. Unless these issues are solved, Mg alloys will be relegated to cast components in non-safety critical applications. A multi-scale approach is required, because key mechanisms operate at different length scales: 1. atomistic (dislocation core interactions with other dislocations and with twin boundaries, and decohesion); 2. microscopic (dislocation-dislocation, dislocation-twin, and twin-twin interactions); 3. mesoscopic (twin-parent grain and grain-grain compatibility interactions leading to backstress and crack initation); and 4. macroscopic (applications to forming simulation or performance prediction design incorporating shear localization). The partners will employ TEM, in situ SEM and electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD) serial imaging techniques, and neutron and synchrotron X ray-based characterization to guide and validate models of the behavior at the corresponding length scales.

These models will greatly aid efforts to render lightweight Mg alloys "formable" and "crushable," so that society can exploit performance and efficiency benefits. This could help reduce potentially harmful greenhouse gas emissions by broader application of lightweight Mg alloys in the transportation sector. Additionally, the multiscale modeling concepts under development can be modified for application to numerous other materials, which deform by similar mechanisms of twinning or martensitic transformation: such as Be, Co, Ti, U, and Zr alloys, Advanced High Strength Steels (e.g. TWIP and TRIP), and shape memory alloys. Finally, the collaboration seeks to develop young scientists and engineers, trained to work in a cutting-edge research environment, providing them with an excellent preparation for future industrial or academic research, which increasingly requires a working knowledge of both theory and experiment.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research collaboration resulted in experimentally validated constitutive models capable of predicting the plastic behavior of Mg alloys. The models account for key features of the alloy, including the orientation of the grains (crystals) within the material. In particular, they account for the effects of the most important mechanical twinning mode within Mg alloys.  This was a critical step for developing materials design concepts to enable the broader use of lightweight Mg alloys in safety critical applications and development of deformation processing strategies.

Intellectual merit: Most structural metals deform by the motion of crystal imperfections known as dislocations. Although the motion and interaction of dislocations remains a topic of research, their behavior is generally well understood. In particular, the type of mechanical behavior exhibited by materials that deform exclusively by dislocation motion is predictable. Among the structural metals employed by engineers, Mg is one of the few that exhibits a deformation mechanism known as twinning. The resulting mechanical behavior is complex, often with a large strength differential between tension and compression as well as directionalities in the properties. This directionality in the properties renders deformation processing at room temperature difficult or impossible (if the deformations demanded are large). The results of the research performed in this project will immediately render the behavior of Mg alloys more predictable, if not improved. In addition, we have identified specific mechanisms that most likely limit the formability and can be addressed in future materials design research.

The specific issue on which this research focused was the rapid strain hardening behavior that can result when the material undergoes extensive deformation twinning. Together with collaborators, we demonstrated a model that can predict the behavior of Mg alloys deformed along arbitrary directions with various starting structures. The model highlighted the fact that the rapid hardening is not due to dislocation-dislocation interactions, or even dislocation-twin boundary interactions. Rather, it is the result of a transition, from twin-dominated flow to flow dominated by the motion of hard dislocation modes. The specific mechanism highlighted as the key to improve the ductility under conditions of twinning intensive deformation is a dislocation known in the scientific community as the <c+a> dislocation. It creates a large discontinuity in the crystal structure, but allows it to deform in ways that no other dislocation in Mg can.

Transmission electron microscopy unequivocally showed, for the first time, that interactions between twin boundaries and dislocations in the surrounding material result in the formation of these special <c+a> dislocations. This observation was made both in pure Mg single crystals as well as polycrystalline Mg alloys. Therefore, we demonstrate that the ductility is not limited by unavailability of the <c+a> dislocations. However, the motion of these dislocations appears to be impeded. Future materials design strategies should focus on means to improve the mobility of these dislocations within the twins.

Broader impact: These models will greatly aid efforts to render lightweight Mg alloys "formable" and "crushable," so that society can exploit performance and efficiency benefits. This could help reduce potentially harmful greenhouse gas emissions by broader application of lightweight Mg alloys in the transportation sector. Additionally, the multiscale modeling developed can be employed to model numerous other materials, which deform by mechanisms of twinning or martensitic transformation: such as Be, Co, Ti, U, and Zr alloys, Advanced High Strength Steels (e.g. TWIP and TRIP), and shape memory alloys. Finally, the collaboration helped to prepare a number of young scientists and engineers, trained to work in a cutting-edge research environment, providing them with an excellent preparation for future industrial, academic, or government research, which increasingly requires a working knowledge of both theory and experiment. 

 


Last Modified: 04/06/2017
Modified by: Sean R Agnew

The models account for key features of the alloy, including the orientation of the grains (crystals) within the material. In particular, they account for the effects of the most important mechanical twinning mode within Mg alloys. This was a critical step for developing materials design concepts to enable the broader use of lightweight Mg alloys in safety critical applications and development of deformation processing strategies. Among the structural metals employed by engineers, Mg is one of the few that exhibits a deformation mechanism known as twinning.
